2d ago13.34 EST

Closing summary

  • Hong Kong is mourning after 83 people were killed in the fire, among them a firefighter and two Indonesian domestic workers.

  • Another 79 people are battling injuries in hospital. And many more people are still waiting to hear from their missing loved ones. Authorities have not given an update on that number – reported earlier on Thursday as more than 250 people.

  • The complex is made up of eight 32-storey towers, containing about 2,000 flats, and were being renovated at the time. About 4,800 people live there.

  • Derek Chan, the deputy fire services director, said their hoses had reached the remaining units still on fire, and flames are expected to be fully out by 9am local time on Friday.

  • The fire department official said their operations had been hampered by the fire’s intense heat.

  • Debris and scaffolding falling from the higher levels had also made access to the buildings difficult, along with the high temperatures and darkness.

  • Three men aged between 52 and 68 were arrested on Thursday morning on suspicion of manslaughter. The trio – two directors and one engineering consultant – worked at a construction company, police said.

  • Police alleged they had reason to believe the company’s responsible parties were “grossly negligent, which led to this accident and caused the fire to spread uncontrollably, resulting in major casualties”.

  • Police did not name the company but later on Thursday searched the office of a construction and engineering company. They seized boxes of documents as evidence, according to local media.

We’ll draw our live coverage of the tragic disaster in Hong Kong to a close now.

The Chinese territory is mourning after eighty three people were kiled in the fire, among them a firefighter and two Indonesian domestic workers.

Another 79 people are battling injuries in hospital. And many more people are still waiting to hear from their missing loves ones. Authorities have not given an update on that number – reported earlier on Thursday as more than 250 people.

2d ago12.52 EST

Anger swelling in Hong Kong over deadliest fire in more than 70 years

Amy Hawkins

As firefighters work to bring the fire under control and make progress with rescue efforts, anger is already swelling among Hongkongers about the causes of the fire.

Hong Kong’s leader John Lee has said the government would set up a HK$300m (£29.2m) fund to help residents and that the city’s development bureau had discussed replacing bamboo scaffolding with metal alternatives.

But some Hongkongers are angry about the focus that has been put on bamboo as a potential accelerant of the fire. On Thursday afternoon, much of the bamboo scaffolding remained standing, with the green mesh between the poles having been incinerated.

The angry people think that blaming bamboo – which the government has already pledged to phase out from public construction works – deflects responsibility from the actual cause of the fire, which is still unknown. Bamboo scaffolding is treasured as an important part of the local heritage, and is something that distinguishes Hong Kong from mainland China, where steel scaffolds are widely used in construction.

Residents of Wang Fuk Court had complained for months about shoddy behaviour from the construction company, said Michael Mo, a former Hong Kong district councillor who now lives in the UK. He was born in the Tai Po area where Wang Fuk Court is located.

Last year, the text of an email purportedly from the Hong Kong labour department was posted on a Wang Fuk Court residents group. Responding to inquiries about the maintenance works, the email said that because the works didn’t involve open flames, “the risk of fire from the scaffolding is relatively low”. It said that the Labour Department’s regulations did not cover flame-retardant standards for scaffolding. The department has been contacted for comment.

The fire has also tapped into the social anxiety in Hong Kong around affordable housing, where sky-high property prices mean that many people live in tightly packed high-rise apartments that can become death traps when disaster strikes.

Updated at 13.06 EST
2d ago12.45 EST

Fire expected to be fully extinguished tonight

There wasn’t too much new information in that fire officials’ press conference but it’s clear they believe their operation is drawing to a close.

Derek Chan, the deputy fire services director, said their hoses had reached the remaining units still on fire, and flames are expected to be fully out by 9am Friday.

Most efforts are now on the search and rescue mission – there were still 25 calls to attend to, Mr Chan said, adding that three of those calls had come in recent hours.

Ambulance official Lam Cheuk-ho reiterated that they had discovered 79 fatalities at the scene. A total of 76 people have been sent to hospital with injuries.

Updated at 13.08 EST
2d ago12.34 EST

The fire department official said their operations had been hampered by the fire’s intense heat.

“We encountered particular difficulties in several areas, like the fire spreading exceptionally fast and rapidly.”

Debris and scaffolding falling from the higher levels had also made access to the buildings difficult, along with the high temperatures and darkness.

That conference has ended now.

We had the update about an hour ago that 83 people have now died from the fire, the majority of whom were found at the scene.

2d ago12.23 EST

Fire officials say their operations to extinguish the fires are nearly complete.

However they are still endeavouring with the search and rescue operation, and will push through the night to reach a remaining group of units in the seven blocks “to ensure there are no other casualties”.

Authorities said they still had 25 outstanding cases where people had called for help.

Updated at 12.20 EST
2d ago12.17 EST

Firefighter killed on Wednesday night named

Earlier on Thursday the fire department had identified Ho Wai-ho, 37, as the firefighter killed in the blaze.

He was found collapsed in the towers about 30 minutes after his colleagues lost contract with him.

Eleven other firefighters have been injured so far, the fire department says.

“Despite the complex conditions at the scene, the firefighters’ rescue efforts will not stop,” Hong Kong’s chief executive John Lee said on Thursday night.

2d ago12.07 EST

We’re expecting a 1am press conference from the fire department shortly. We can expect more information on the fatalities and number of people still trapped in the towers then.

Share
Updated at 12.07 EST
2d ago11.24 EST

Death roll rises to 83

Hong Kong fire services say the number of dead has now risen to 83 people, as of Thursday midnight local time.

At least 75 people are injured, and there are still at least 250 reported missing.

Police have alleged flammable scaffolding and foam materials used during maintenance work may have been behind the rapid spread of the deadliest fire in the city in decades.

Share
Updated at 11.27 EST
2d ago11.13 EST

What we know about the criminal negligence alleged

Hong Kong and Chinese authorities moved swiftly the day after the fire in arresting the bosses of a construction firm contracted to carry out the buildings’ maintenance.

Police said they had arrested two directors and an engineering consultant on suspicion of manslaughter.

Hong Kong police superintendent Eileen Chung said:

“We have reason to believe the company’s responsible parties were grossly negligent, which led to this accident and caused the fire to spread uncontrollably, resulting in major casualties”.

They did not name the company but later on Thursday searched the firm’s offices where they seized boxes of documents as evidence.

The government separately identified the registered contractor for the Wang Fuk Court buildings as Prestige Construction and Engineering Company.

At a press conference on Thursday, officials said they had checked the safety standards of 11 other sites maintained by Prestige.

Share
Updated at 11.22 EST
2d ago10.57 EST

As the scale of the tragedy becomes clearer, leaders around the world have turned to Hong Kong to offer condolences.

A “saddened” Pope Leo issued a statement sending “spiritual solidarity to all those suffering … especially the injured and the families who grieve”.

Russian President Vladimir Putin has also sent a message to his ally, China’s leader Xi Jinping, Russian media reported.
